expanded_description: Review questions provide comprehensive practice integrating all motion and graphing concepts from Chapter 3. These problems test understanding of position, velocity, acceleration, graphs, uniform motion, and constant acceleration kinematics.

core_concept.principle: Review questions synthesize motion concepts learned throughout the chapter, testing both conceptual understanding and problem-solving skills across position-time graphs, velocity-time graphs, kinematic equations, and motion analysis.
core_concept.explanation: This section brings together all motion topics: describing motion using position, displacement, distance, speed, and velocity; understanding acceleration as rate of velocity change; interpreting position-time and velocity-time graphs (slopes, areas, shapes); applying uniform motion equations; and using kinematic equations for constant acceleration including free fall. Success requires understanding both concepts (why relationships work, what graphs mean) and procedures (how to calculate, which equations to use). The questions progress from basic recall to application and multi-step analysis, mirroring how motion skills are used in real physics problems.

sections.introduction: These questions test grasp of fundamental motion concepts without requiring extensive calculations.

worked_examples.title: Question 1: Position vs Displacement
worked_examples.problem: Explain the difference between position and displacement. Give an example where they are equal and an example where they differ.

step_by_step.explanation: Position is location relative to origin at a specific time. Vector quantity with sign indicating direction from origin.
Displacement is change in position: $\Delta x = x_f - x_i$. Straight-line distance from start to finish with direction.
Object starts at origin, moves to $x = 50$ m in straight line. Position at end: 50 m. Displacement: $50 - 0 = 50$ m. Equal.
Object at $x = 20$ m moves to $x = 80$ m then back to $x = 30$ m. Final position: 30 m. Displacement: $30 - 20 = 10$ m (net change). Different values.

worked_examples.final_answer: Position is location relative to origin. Displacement is change in position (net movement from start to finish). Equal when starting at origin with straight-line motion in one direction. Different when starting position ≠ 0 or when path involves direction changes.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Understanding distinction between where you are (position) and how far you've moved net (displacement).

worked_examples.title: Question 2: Speed vs Velocity
worked_examples.problem: Two cars are both traveling at 60 km/h. Can they have different velocities? Explain with an example.

step_by_step.explanation: Speed is scalar (magnitude only). Velocity is vector (magnitude and direction).
Yes, they can have different velocities even with same speed if moving in different directions.
Car A: traveling 60 km/h north. Velocity = +60 km/h. Car B: traveling 60 km/h south. Velocity = -60 km/h (or 60 km/h south). Same speed (60 km/h), opposite velocities.

worked_examples.final_answer: Yes. Speed is magnitude only; velocity includes direction. Two cars at 60 km/h have same speed but different velocities if traveling in different directions (e.g., one north, one south).
worked_examples.concept_applied: Speed is scalar; velocity is vector. Same speed doesn't mean same velocity if directions differ.

worked_examples.title: Question 3: Acceleration Sign Interpretation
worked_examples.problem: An object has velocity $v = +15$ m/s and acceleration $a = -3$ m/s². Is it speeding up or slowing down? Explain.

step_by_step.explanation: Velocity: positive (moving in + direction). Acceleration: negative (in - direction). Opposite signs.
When velocity and acceleration have opposite signs, object is slowing down.
Moving forward (+) but acceleration backward (-) means braking, decelerating, slowing down.
After 1 s: $v = 15 + (-3)(1) = 12$ m/s. After 2 s: $v = 15 + (-3)(2) = 9$ m/s. Velocity decreasing—confirming slowing down.

worked_examples.final_answer: Slowing down. Velocity (+) and acceleration (-) have opposite signs, indicating deceleration. Object moving in positive direction but acceleration opposes motion.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Opposite signs for $v$ and $a$ mean slowing down. Same signs mean speeding up.

worked_examples.title: Question 4: Position-Time Graph Interpretation
worked_examples.problem: What does a horizontal line on a position-time graph indicate? What about the slope of the line?

step_by_step.explanation: Horizontal line: position not changing with time. $\Delta x = 0$.
No position change means no motion. Object is at rest (stationary).
Slope = $\Delta x / \Delta t = 0 / \Delta t = 0$. Slope equals velocity.
Zero slope means zero velocity. Object not moving.

worked_examples.final_answer: Horizontal line on x-t graph indicates object at rest (stationary). Position constant, no motion. Slope = 0, meaning velocity = 0.
worked_examples.concept_applied: On position-time graph: slope = velocity. Horizontal line (slope = 0) means stationary object.

worked_examples.title: Question 5: Velocity-Time Graph and Displacement
worked_examples.problem: How do you find displacement from a velocity-time graph? Why does this method work?

step_by_step.explanation: Calculate area under the velocity-time curve between the curve and the time axis.
From definition: $v = \Delta x / \Delta t$, rearranging: $\Delta x = v \cdot \Delta t$. On graph, $v \times \Delta t$ is rectangular area (height × width).
Area above axis (positive $v$) = positive displacement. Area below axis (negative $v$) = negative displacement.
Total displacement = sum of signed areas under v-t curve.

worked_examples.final_answer: Calculate area under v-t curve. Works because displacement = velocity × time, and v × Δt equals rectangular area on graph. Areas above axis are positive displacement; areas below are negative displacement.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Area under v-t curve = displacement, from relationship $\Delta x = v \Delta t$.

worked_examples.title: Question 6: Free Fall Misconception
worked_examples.problem: True or False: When a ball thrown upward reaches its highest point, its acceleration is zero. Explain.

step_by_step.explanation: FALSE
At highest point: velocity = 0 (momentarily stops)
Acceleration = $-g = -9.8$ m/s² (downward) throughout entire motion—including at the peak.
If acceleration were zero at peak, ball would float there forever. Gravity continues pulling downward, causing ball to fall back down.
Students often confuse velocity = 0 with acceleration = 0. At peak: $v = 0$ but $a = -g$ (not zero).

worked_examples.final_answer: FALSE. At peak, velocity = 0 (momentarily), but acceleration = -g = -9.8 m/s² (downward) still. Gravity doesn't stop pulling. Common mistake: confusing zero velocity with zero acceleration.
worked_examples.concept_applied: In free fall, acceleration is constant $-g$ throughout—going up, at peak, coming down. Never zero.

sections.introduction: Practice reading and interpreting position-time and velocity-time graphs.

worked_examples.title: Question 7: Reading Position-Time Graph
worked_examples.problem: A position-time graph shows a straight line from $(0 \text{ s}, 10 \text{ m})$ to $(8 \text{ s}, 50 \text{ m})$. Find: (a) initial position, (b) final position, (c) displacement, (d) velocity.

step_by_step.explanation: At $t = 0$: read position from graph
At $t = 8$ s: read position from graph
$\Delta x = x_f - x_i = 50 - 10$
Slope of x-t graph = velocity. $v = \frac{\Delta x}{\Delta t} = \frac{50 - 10}{8 - 0}$

worked_examples.concept_applied: Reading x-t graph: intercepts give positions, difference gives displacement, slope gives velocity.

worked_examples.title: Question 8: Velocity-Time Graph Analysis
worked_examples.problem: A v-t graph shows a horizontal line at $v = 8$ m/s from $t = 0$ to $t = 5$ s. Find: (a) acceleration, (b) displacement during this time.

step_by_step.explanation: Acceleration = slope of v-t graph. Horizontal line has slope = 0.
Displacement = area under v-t curve. Rectangle: width = 5 s, height = 8 m/s

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) $a = 0$ m/s² (uniform motion), (b) $\Delta x = 40$ m
worked_examples.concept_applied: On v-t graph: slope = acceleration, area = displacement. Horizontal line = zero acceleration.

worked_examples.title: Question 9: Interpreting Graph Shapes
worked_examples.problem: Match each description to graph type (x-t or v-t) and shape: (a) Object at rest, (b) Constant velocity motion, (c) Constant acceleration from rest, (d) Object slowing down uniformly.

step_by_step.explanation: x-t graph: horizontal line (position constant). v-t graph: line on axis at $v = 0$ (zero velocity).
x-t graph: straight sloped line (linear position change). v-t graph: horizontal line above or below axis (constant non-zero velocity).
x-t graph: upward parabola starting at origin (quadratic). v-t graph: straight sloped line from origin (velocity increasing linearly).
x-t graph: parabola flattening (slope decreasing). v-t graph: straight line with negative slope approaching axis (velocity decreasing linearly to zero).

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) x-t: horizontal; v-t: on axis. (b) x-t: straight slope; v-t: horizontal. (c) x-t: parabola; v-t: straight from origin. (d) x-t: flattening curve; v-t: negative slope.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Graph shapes reveal motion type: straight vs curved, horizontal vs sloped indicate different motion characteristics.

worked_examples.title: Question 10: Multiple Segments
worked_examples.problem: Describe the motion for a v-t graph with three segments: (1) $t = 0$ to $3$ s: $v = 0$ to $v = 15$ m/s (straight line), (2) $t = 3$ to $7$ s: $v = 15$ m/s (horizontal), (3) $t = 7$ to $10$ s: $v = 15$ m/s to $v = 0$ (straight line).

step_by_step.explanation: Velocity increasing from 0 to 15 m/s linearly. Straight upward slope → constant positive acceleration. Starting from rest, speeding up.
Velocity constant at 15 m/s. Horizontal line → zero acceleration. Uniform motion (cruising).
Velocity decreasing from 15 to 0 m/s linearly. Straight downward slope → constant negative acceleration. Slowing to stop.

worked_examples.final_answer: Segment 1: Accelerating from rest at +5 m/s². Segment 2: Constant velocity 15 m/s (a=0). Segment 3: Decelerating at -5 m/s² to stop. Classic acceleration-cruise-deceleration pattern.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Multi-segment v-t graph: analyze each segment separately. Slopes give accelerations for each phase.

sections.introduction: Apply kinematic equations to solve constant acceleration problems.

worked_examples.title: Question 11: Uniform Acceleration
worked_examples.problem: A car accelerates from rest at $a = 3.5$ m/s² for 8.0 seconds. Find: (a) final velocity, (b) displacement.

step_by_step.explanation: $v_i = 0$ (from rest), $a = 3.5$ m/s², $\Delta t = 8.0$ s
Use $v_f = v_i + a\Delta t$
Use $\Delta x = v_i \Delta t + \frac{1}{2}a(\Delta t)^2$

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) $v_f = 28$ m/s, (b) $\Delta x = 112$ m
worked_examples.concept_applied: From rest: $v_i = 0$. Use equation (1) for velocity, equation (2) for displacement.

worked_examples.title: Question 12: Braking Distance
worked_examples.problem: A car traveling at 30 m/s brakes with $a = -6$ m/s². How far does it travel before stopping?

step_by_step.explanation: $v_i = 30$ m/s, $v_f = 0$ (stops), $a = -6$ m/s²
Know $v_i$, $v_f$, $a$; need $\Delta x$; don't need $\Delta t$. Use equation (3): $v_f^2 = v_i^2 + 2a\Delta x$

worked_examples.final_answer: $\Delta x = 75$ m (stopping distance)
worked_examples.concept_applied: Stops: $v_f = 0$. Time not given/needed: use equation (3).

worked_examples.title: Question 13: Time to Reach Velocity
worked_examples.problem: A bicycle accelerates at $a = 2.0$ m/s² from initial velocity $v_i = 4.0$ m/s. How long to reach $v_f = 16$ m/s?

step_by_step.explanation: $v_f = v_i + a\Delta t$ → $\Delta t = \frac{v_f - v_i}{a}$

worked_examples.final_answer: $\Delta t = 6.0$ s
worked_examples.concept_applied: Rearrange $v_f = v_i + a\Delta t$ to find time.

worked_examples.title: Question 14: Two-Step Problem
worked_examples.problem: A train accelerates from rest at $a = 1.5$ m/s² for 20 s, then travels at constant velocity for 30 s. Find total displacement.

step_by_step.explanation: $v_i = 0$, $a = 1.5$ m/s², $\Delta t = 20$ s. Use $\Delta x = v_i \Delta t + \frac{1}{2}a(\Delta t)^2$

step_by_step.step: Find velocity at end of phase 1
step_by_step.explanation: $v_f = v_i + a\Delta t = 0 + 1.5(20) = 30$ m/s. This becomes $v_i$ for phase 2.
$v = 30$ m/s (constant), $\Delta t = 30$ s. Uniform motion: $\Delta x = v\Delta t$
$\Delta x_{\text{total}} = \Delta x_1 + \Delta x_2 = 300 + 900$

worked_examples.final_answer: Total displacement = 1200 m
worked_examples.concept_applied: Multi-phase motion: solve each phase separately, then sum displacements. Phase 1 final velocity becomes phase 2 initial velocity.

worked_examples.title: Question 15: Free Fall Problem
worked_examples.problem: A ball is dropped from rest from a height of 80 m. (a) How long to hit ground? (b) What is its impact velocity?

step_by_step.explanation: Upward = +. Dropped from rest: $v_i = 0$. Falls downward: $\Delta x = -80$ m. Gravity: $a = -9.8$ m/s²
Use $\Delta x = v_i \Delta t + \frac{1}{2}a(\Delta t)^2$. With $v_i = 0$: $\Delta x = \frac{1}{2}a(\Delta t)^2$
Use $v_f^2 = v_i^2 + 2a\Delta x = 0 + 2(-9.8)(-80) = 1568$. $v_f = -\sqrt{1568} = -39.6$ m/s (take negative root—moving down)

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) $\Delta t = 4.04$ s, (b) $v_f = -39.6$ m/s (downward, speed 39.6 m/s)
worked_examples.concept_applied: Free fall: $a = -g = -9.8$ m/s² constantly. Dropped from rest: $v_i = 0$. Downward displacement and velocity are negative.

sections.introduction: More complex problems requiring integration of multiple concepts.

worked_examples.title: Question 16: Meeting Point
worked_examples.problem: Car A starts from rest and accelerates at $a = 4$ m/s². Car B passes A at constant velocity 20 m/s when A starts. When and where does A catch up to B?

step_by_step.explanation: Car A: $x_A = 0 + 0(t) + \frac{1}{2}(4)t^2 = 2t^2$. Car B: $x_B = 0 + 20t$ (constant velocity, starts at same position)
When A catches B: $x_A = x_B$, so $2t^2 = 20t$
$2t^2 - 20t = 0$ → $2t(t - 10) = 0$. Solutions: $t = 0$ (start) or $t = 10$ s

worked_examples.final_answer: A catches B at $t = 10$ s, position $x = 200$ m
worked_examples.concept_applied: Meeting point: set position equations equal. One accelerating, one constant velocity.

worked_examples.title: Question 17: Thrown Upward and Back
worked_examples.problem: A ball is thrown upward at $v_i = 20$ m/s from ground level. (a) Maximum height? (b) Time in air? (c) Impact velocity?

step_by_step.explanation: Upward = +. $v_i = +20$ m/s, $a = -9.8$ m/s²
At peak: $v_f = 0$. Use $v_f^2 = v_i^2 + 2a\Delta x$
Symmetry: time up = time down, or use $\Delta x = 0$ (returns to ground). Use $\Delta x = v_i \Delta t + \frac{1}{2}a(\Delta t)^2$ with $\Delta x = 0$
step_by_step.calculation: $0 = 20\Delta t + \frac{1}{2}(-9.8)(\Delta t)^2$ → $0 = 20\Delta t - 4.9(\Delta t)^2$ → $0 = \Delta t(20 - 4.9\Delta t)$. $\Delta t = 0$ or $\Delta t = \frac{20}{4.9} = 4.08$ s

step_by_step.explanation: Symmetry: lands with same speed as launch, opposite direction. $v_f = -20$ m/s. Or use $v_f = v_i + a\Delta t = 20 + (-9.8)(4.08) = 20 - 40 = -20$ m/s

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) Max height = 20.4 m, (b) Time in air = 4.08 s, (c) Impact velocity = -20 m/s (downward)
worked_examples.concept_applied: Upward throw: at peak $v = 0$. Symmetry: time up = time down, return speed = launch speed (opposite direction).

worked_examples.title: Question 18: Graph to Equation
worked_examples.problem: A v-t graph shows velocity increasing from $v = 5$ m/s at $t = 0$ to $v = 25$ m/s at $t = 10$ s (straight line). Write equations for: (a) acceleration, (b) velocity as function of time, (c) position as function of time (assume $x_i = 0$).

step_by_step.explanation: Slope of v-t graph. $a = \frac{\Delta v}{\Delta t} = \frac{25 - 5}{10 - 0} = \frac{20}{10}$
Use $x = x_i + v_i t + \frac{1}{2}at^2$ with $x_i = 0$, $v_i = 5$, $a = 2$

worked_examples.concept_applied: From v-t graph: slope gives $a$, use to write $v(t)$ and $x(t)$ equations.

worked_examples.title: Question 19: Relative Motion
worked_examples.problem: Train A travels at constant 30 m/s. Train B starts from rest 200 m behind A and accelerates at 2 m/s². Does B catch A? If so, when and where?

step_by_step.explanation: Train A: $x_A = 200 + 30t$ (starts 200 m ahead, constant velocity). Train B: $x_B = 0 + 0(t) + \frac{1}{2}(2)t^2 = t^2$ (starts at origin, accelerating)
B is accelerating, A is constant velocity. Eventually B will be faster and can catch up. Set $x_B = x_A$: $t^2 = 200 + 30t$

worked_examples.final_answer: Yes, B catches A at $t \approx 35.6$ s, position $x \approx 1270$ m
worked_examples.concept_applied: Relative motion: faster accelerating object eventually catches slower constant-velocity object. Solve quadratic equation.

worked_examples.title: Question 20: Comprehensive Problem
worked_examples.problem: A car travels at 25 m/s, then brakes uniformly for 5 s, reducing speed to 10 m/s. It then accelerates uniformly for 8 s, reaching 30 m/s. Find: (a) acceleration during braking, (b) distance during braking, (c) acceleration during speeding up, (d) distance during speeding up, (e) total displacement.

step_by_step.explanation: $v_i = 25$ m/s, $v_f = 10$ m/s, $\Delta t = 5$ s. $a = \frac{v_f - v_i}{\Delta t} = \frac{10 - 25}{5}$
$\Delta x_{\text{total}} = \Delta x_1 + \Delta x_2 = 87.5 + 160$

worked_examples.concept_applied: Multi-phase problem: analyze each phase separately using appropriate equations, then combine results.

summary: Chapter 3 review questions integrate all motion topics: fundamental concepts (position vs displacement, speed vs velocity, scalars vs vectors), acceleration understanding (rate of velocity change, sign interpretation for speeding up vs slowing down), graph interpretation (position-time: slope = velocity, velocity-time: slope = acceleration and area = displacement), graph shapes (straight lines = uniform motion, curves = acceleration, horizontal = constant or zero values), kinematic equations for constant acceleration (four equations relating $v_i$, $v_f$, $a$, $\Delta t$, $\Delta x$), problem-solving strategy (list knowns, choose appropriate equation, solve algebraically, check reasonableness), and free fall applications (constant $g = 9.8$ m/s² downward, at peak $v = 0$ but $a = -g$ still). Success requires understanding concepts (why relationships work, what signs mean, how graphs connect to motion) and mastering procedures (reading graphs, choosing correct equations, applying sign conventions, multi-step problem decomposition). Common skills tested: calculating velocity from position change or graph slope, finding acceleration from velocity change or graph slope, determining displacement from velocity-time area, using kinematic equations with proper equation selection, interpreting motion from graph shapes, solving free fall problems with gravity, analyzing multi-phase motion by breaking into segments, applying sign conventions consistently. The review emphasizes integration—using multiple concepts together to solve realistic problems, just as required in physics applications beyond this chapter.
